title: Michael Avenatti Found Guilty of Stealing From Stormy Daniels; Jury convicts lawyer of stealing nearly $300,000 from his former client
text:
Mr. Avenatti clasped his hands and looked at the jury while U.S. District Judge Jesse Furman read the verdict. Afterward he looked down and closed his eyes. Judge Furman set a sentencing date for May 24. He also ordered Mr. Avenatti to report to prison in California on Monday to begin serving his sentence in a separate federal conviction.

Outside the courtroom, Mr. Avenatti expressed disappointment in the jury's verdict. "I am looking forward to a full adjudication of all of the issues on appeal," he said.

When asked if he regretted representing himself, he said, "No, not at all."

Clark Brewster, a lawyer for Ms. Daniels, said his client was pleased the justice system worked. "Stormy is relieved this nightmare is over," he said in a statement.

It is the second federal criminal conviction of Mr. Avenatti, the brash television lawyer whose ascent to stardom was tied to his quest to take down former President Donald Trump. In addition to representing Ms. Daniels in her legal battles against the former president, he publicly contemplated a 2020 presidential run.

His rise abruptly ended in 2019, when he was indicted in connection with what federal prosecutors said was an attempt to extort more than $20 million from Nike Inc. After a trial in 2020, Mr. Avenatti was convicted of three criminal counts and sentenced to 2 Â½ years in prison. He has appealed that conviction. Last year, in California, he represented himself in a second federal trial that ended in a mistrial.

In the latest case, Manhattan federal prosecutors accused Mr. Avenatti of stealing a portion of the advance for Ms. Daniels' memoir, "Full Disclosure," then lying to his onetime client to cover it up. Prosecutors said Mr. Avenatti sent a fake letter from Ms. Daniels to her literary agent. The letter instructed that book payments be sent to an account controlled by Mr. Avenatti.

"He was supposed to be her advocate, but the defendant betrayed her trust," Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert Sobelman said during closing arguments.

Mr. Avenatti portrayed the dispute as an argument over fees. "According to the government, Michael Avenatti could never believe that he actually had a right to be paid," Mr. Avenatti told the jury. "That is ludicrous."

Ms. Daniels, whose given name is Stephanie Clifford, served as prosecutors' star witness.
